newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila plans rice imports in case of drought.
newsitem.headline: Manila plans rice imports in case of drought.

text.p: The Philippines, pressed by the private sector to book early rice imports for delivery in the first half of 1998 due to threats of a drought, can immediately import 350,000 tonnes in case of a production shortfall, a senior official said.

Agriculture Secretary Salvador Escudero said the state-owned National Food Authority has a "standby authority" to import 350,000 tonnes of rice - enough to meet the country's requirement for 15 days - in case of an emergency situation.
But Escudero said any decision to import rice would depend on the volume of rice harvests next month.
"We don't know yet how bad El Nino will hit us," he said.
The weather bureau has predicted a drought in the Philippines starting in the last quarter of this year because of El Nino and said it could be the worst to hit the country in 16 years.

The Philippines has suffered severe drops in crop harvests, particularly rice, as a result of at least five droughts caused by the El Nino phenomena since 1982, said Rolando Dy, executive director of the Center for Food and Agribusinesss at Manila's University of Asia and the Pacific.

El Nino is caused by the warming of water in the western Pacific Ocean, which interacts with other weather systems and typically produces freak weather, such as drought in some areas and heavier-than-normal rainfall in others.

Dy said he expected Philippine rice output to drop by 15 percent to 2.7 million tonnes in the first half of 1998 from 3.2 million in the first half of 1997. --Manila newsroom (63 2) 841-8936, Fax 817-6267
